The postmaster general has decided to continue the service, reversing a decision to end 50 years of weekly flights into the mountainous wilderness of Idaho.
NPR's Howard Berkes reports.
The Postal Service cited a $6 billion deficit and $46,000 in savings when it canceled the weekly mail plane route.

Listen carefully because Tims called on a satellite that doesn't work well deep down in the Salmon River Canyon he calls home.

There's a number of ridges and mountains that go up to about 7,000 or 8,000 feet.

Actually, this time of year, you probably couldn't do it at all given the snow in the passes.
Now, Tims could also drive to the post office box.
That first involves four miles of hiking, then six miles on a kidney-crushing dirt road hugging a canyon wall, and then about 250 more miles of gravel and pavement.
Similar expeditions faced 20 other ranches, lodges and a university research station scattered throughout Central Idaho wilderness.
